Award.AwardTitle: International Planning Visit for US-Korea Undergraduate Research in Smart Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will initiate international education and research partnerships with Korean universities in the field of smart materials and systems. The planning visit will support the PI and two undergraduate students to visit KAIST and KIMM.

This project will provide international collaborative research and education opportunities to US undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objectives of the planning visit research were to conduct preliminary research on smart or active materials, to develop a long-term collaborative research plan with Korean counterparts, and to explore international education partnerships with Korean universities. To fulfill these goals, the PI and two undergraduate students in the Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering at Miami University of Ohio visited Republic of Korea for 10 days and conducted international collaborative research on magneto-rheological materials (MREs). MREs are a new class of smart materials, whose modulus (i.e., stiffness or harness) can be controlled by the applied magnetic field. The MRE materials have received growing attention because of their versatility and potential engineering applications as novel actuators. In particular, the PI and his students investigated a new generation of MREs based on hard magnetic particles (neodymium) or H-MREs.

During their planning visit, the PI and his students conducted research at Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST), focusing on experimentally characterizing the dynamic behaviors of H-MREs. They set up H-MRE samples in a cantilevered configuration (i.e., fixed-free condition) and measured the displacement and blocked force at the free-end of the H-MRE samples under varying magnetic fields using precision sensors along with a custom made electromagnet setup. The experimental results show that H-MREs exhibit large blocked force and displacement as compared with other smart materials in comparable dimensions. Moreover, the bending motion of the H-MREs can be activated using small amount power (magnetic fields). These results show substantial intellectual merits of the new MREs as new controllable bending actuators for various engineering applications. The applications of H-MREs can impact the development of novel actuators for small electronic devices and mechanical systems, such as electronic Braille systems.

The outcomes of the project have broader impacts. The planning visit research provided an excellent opportunity for the two US students to gain invaluable international research as well as multicultural experiences in their early carrier. Another broader impact resulting from this project was that the student participants and the PI developed several educational videos on smart materials and hands-on demonstrations to widely disseminate the outcomes of the project and experiences. They presented those materials and demonstrations to nearly 150 girls (5-6 grade students from the greater Cincinnati area schools) at an annual Girl Scout Day (GSD), one of the STEM events at Miami University. The PI also incorporated the materials in his classroom as special topics to enhance student learning experiences in undergraduate engineering curriculum.
